BusinessName.BusinessNameLine1Txt: TRUSTEES OF THE HAMLINE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: At Hamline, our mission is to create a diverse and collaborative community of learners dedicated to the development of students' knowledge, values, and skills for successful lives of leadership, scholarship, and service.
IRS990.MissionDesc: Hamline University is a nationally ranked comprehensive university serving 3,400 students in its College of Liberal Arts, School of Education, and School of Business. It offers undergraduate, masters, doctorate and professional degrees, as well as certificate and continuing studies programs.
IRS990.Desc: Hamline University is a nationally-ranked, comprehensive university serving nearly 3,400 students in its College of Liberal Arts, School of Education, and School of Business. It offers undergraduate, masters, doctoral and professional degrees, as well as certificate and continuing studies programs. Founded in 1854, Hamline University was the first institution of higher learning in Minnesota. The University has established a national reputation for academic quality, as well as providing students with personal attention and high-impact learning experiences. Hamline is one of just 290 Phi Beta Kappa institutions in the United States. Among comprehensive universities, U.S. News and World Report ranks Hamline as one of the top-ranked Minnesota universities in its category of Best Regional Universities.

ProgSrvcAccomActy2Grp.Desc: Hamline University provides academic support to its students through support services that are an integral part of the University's primary mission of instruction. This includes expenses for libraries, galleries, audio/visual services, academic development, academic computing support, course and curriculum development, and academic administration. The revenue includes contracts.

ProgSrvcAccomActy3Grp.Desc: Hamline University provides student services to its students and includes such expenses as admissions, financial aid, administration, registrar activities, and activities that contribute to students' emotional and physical well-being and to their intellectual, cultural, and social development outside the context of the formal instructional program.

ProgSrvcAccomActyOtherGrp.Desc: Hamline University provides auxiliary services to students which are essentially the self supporting operations of the University. These services charge a fee to students that is directly related to, although not necessarily equal to, the cost of providing the service. Examples are residence halls, student health services, and the campus bookstore.
Expenditures of those offices and activities whose primary purpose is to support the program activities of the University.

ProgramServiceRevenueGrp.Desc: Sales and Services of Educational Activities

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The University is a member of Minnesota Private College Council (MPCC), an organization described in section 501(c)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code. MPCC is an association of private nonprofit institutions of higher education that serves a variety of its members' shared needs, including, but not only, nonpartisan and non-electoral advocacy for public policy that meets students' needs and advances the interests of private higher education. The University paid membership dues to MPCC in the amount of $144,929 during the taxable year. MPCC has divided its expenses for its taxable year ending June 30, 2021, into two groups. Group 1 consists of those expenses that did not in any way support attempts to influence legislation within the meaning of section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code ("lobbying"), and Group 2 consists of all other expenses. Group 2 includes many expenses, such as personnel costs, that supported both lobbying and nonlobbying activities. MPCC did not attempt to allocate the Group 2 expenses between lobbying and nonlobbying activities. MPCC has determined that the amount of the Group 2 expenses represents 78.13% of the amount of the dues that MPCC collected in the same taxable year. Assuming that all Group 2 expenses were paid from member dues, and allocating those expenses pro rata based on the dues paid by each member, $115,609 of the University's dues were used to pay Group 2 expenses. The amount of lobbying expenses paid from the University's dues was significantly less than that amount. This amount of Group 2 expenses are shown in Conferences, Conventions and Meetings, Part IX, line 19.

The University's collections, which were acquired through purchases and contributions since the University's inception, are not recognized as assets on the balance sheet. Purchases of collection items are recorded as decreases in net assets without donor restrictions in the year in which the items are acquired or as net assets with donor restrictions if the assets that are used to purchase the items are restricted by the donors. Contributed collection items are not reflected on the financial statements. Proceeds from de-accessions or insurance recoveries are reflected as increases in the appropriate net asset classes.

The University's collection is made up of pottery, prints, musical instruments and paintings that are held for educational and performance purposes. Each of the items is catalogued, preserved and cared for and activities verifying their existence and assessing their condition are performed continuously.

The intended uses of the endowment funds are to establish a scholarship or prize, to create a chair in a specific academic area, to fund a particular research program, to fund other programs such as professorships, fellowships, library, buildings, equipment and lectures and discretionary use by the University (unrestricted).
Represents annuities and unitrusts and the right of use liability for operating and financing leases. See schedule.

The University publicizes its racially nondiscriminatory position in all major publications, including those related to admission and student services and Hamline Magazine as well as on the University website.
The University receives federal and state funding, including CARES Act funding.

AccountActivitiesOutsideUSGrp.RegionTxt: North America (including Canada and Mexico, but not the United States)

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: University does not monitor academic achievement of recipients for the purpose of qualification for assistance.

GrantsOtherAsstToIndivInUSGrp.GrantTypeTxt: Educational scholarships and financial assistance for undergraduate students

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The financial aid office determines students eligibility for federal, state, and institutional scholarships according to the University's established criteria which follows federal and state guidelines for awarding any grant funds. There is an annual audit to ensure compliance with these regulations.
The president has been provided these items by the University.
The President of the University participates in a supplemental nonquaified retirement plan.
A written contract between the University and its President provides for a non-fixed payment. This payment is discretionary. This payment is reflected in Schedule J, Part II, Column B(ii).

TaxExemptBondsIssuesGrp.PurposeDesc: REFUND OF PRIOR BOND AND REFINANCE A LOAN
PREPAY A PRIOR LOAN AND ADVANCE REFUND A PRIOR BOND

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, Line 4
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Prior to 10/15/2020, trustees of the University were nominated by the Board of Trustees and elected by the Minnesota Annual Conference of the United Methodist Church. The Articles of Incorporation were amended effective 10/15/2020 such that the Board of Trustees are elected by the Trustees.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 11b
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Form 990 was reviewed by management and the executive committee prior to being filed with the IRS. The Form 990 was provided to the Board of Trustees.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 12c
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Executive committee of the Board of Trustees is responsible for monitoring and responding to conflicts of interest. An individual with a conflict of interest is required to abstain from discussions and voting on the issue.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 15
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The determination of compensation for the individuals identified included review and approval by independent persons, review of comparability data and contemporaneous substantiation of the decision.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, Line 19
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The University's governing documents are available at the Minnesota Secretary of State's office. The University's audited financial statements are available on its website. The University's Form 990 is available at Guidestar.org or upon request. The University's conflict of interest policy is available to the public on its website.
Change in value of split interest agreements.
